answers.answer: Hi Kevin:The first thing I would tell you is not to panic, and it's been my experience that you have come to the right place for answers.The AST/ALT levels are not an indicator as to how long or even how mild the virus is. A liver biopsy is a must, it will best tell you how severe the virus has affected your liver. You have very likely had this virus for years, my husband has been infected for probably 25+ years before being detected in April. Genotype and viral load are also important. Both will give you some indication of what is to come, but neither are the sole factors in determining your outcome. My husband had an ultra sound and CT scan and neither of them picked up any problems with his liver, yet the biopsy showed him at grade 1 inflammation and stage 3 liver disease, so treatment was a must for him. He also had a viral load of 9,230,000 and is genotype 1B, but after only 3 weeks of treatment his PCR came back <10. You have much to learn in the coming weeks and I have found this board to be the best. Everyone will be here for you.My thoughts are with you and yours,Debbe

Kevin,When I was diagnosed seven weeks ago (I'm 44, by the way), I thought I had been handed a death sentence.  It was such a blow to be told I have a serious condition -- especially since I've always been a bit of a health-nut.  Like you, I didn't fit into any of the typical risk profiles of someone with HCV.Now, seven weeks later, and with the benefit of knowing more information: i.e. my genotype (1a), my viral load (very, very low); and liver biopsy results (moderate inflammation, no significant fibrosis), I feel like I have a future again.  My initial sense of panic and terror have subsided.  I had imagined the very worst (dead in a few months), but the reality didn't come anywhere close to that.I know it's hard not to be afraid when so much is still "unknown," but please try to keep a level head during the next few weeks.  The folks here are very kind and have a wealth of information to share.  They've helped me put things into perspective on several occassions.Hang in there Kevin.  My thoughts and prayers are with you.Susan

Hi, Kevin.  Sorry you are eligible for our group, but welcome.  Please scan through recent posts, you'll find a lot of good information.  For now, relax a little as you move forward, this is not a fast moving disease.I hope you get the genotype and viral load info soon.  If you're a type 2 or 3, you may not even have a biopsy done, since the odds of treatment success are so high; with other genotypes, the biopsy is necessary to help guide your decisions.  Your ALT and AST are not incredibly high, but they suggest inflammation or other ongoing activity in the liver.  Finding out where or how you got the virus is pretty immaterial; it's here, and we have to proceed from the current conditions.In the grand scheme of things, you are still young.With diabetes as a factor, make sure you are working closely with a very good doctor; hope you find the new gastro informed, communicative, and comfortable to be with.Keep us posted, please.Best wishes,Maj Neni

I just wanted to say don't be unduly worried about the sharing of clippers and toothbrushes, although obviously you will want to stop those practices in the name of common sense.My husband probably had the virus for 20 years before we found out.  We shared toothbrushes on lots of  occasions, have had "plenty" of opporotunities to pass the virus on to each other (if you get my drift), and I often tended his cuts and boo-boo's without gloves before we knew.  (shamefully, I still don't worry about his blood, but he is now a sustained responder and is undetectable and I just don't worry about it).  If anyone should have gotten it from him, it would be me, and I am neg.He is a type 3, supposedly the easiest to treat, yet relapsed after his first treatment and had to do a second, year long treatment.  I am glad we had the biopsy even though they aren't recommending them for 3's, b/c he does have cirrhosis.Good luck to you, stay calm, I don't think your family is in any danger.  I hope your wife's test is negative.  Read all you can, learn all you can, and be at peace with yourself on this new journey.

My wife just got her results back on the panel. Positive for HCV. We had the kids tested today.

I'm sorry to hear the news about your wife.  I'm not entirely surprised, though.  When you originally posted your story, it sounded to me as if she was the one who might have originally contracted Hep C through the blood transfusion and then passed it on to you.  I don't have a crystal ball, of course, but I'd bet that none of your kids are infected.  However, I know you and your wife must be on pins and needles waiting for the results.There are several regular posters here who share similar circumstances with you -- both they and their spouses are infected. I'm sure they can give you a lot of good advice and support.I know how devastating these recent turn of events must seem to your family right now.  Somehow, I've come to find peace in the midst of my own HCV storm by reminding myself that this is a battle that CAN be won.  Many people on this planet are facing much greater struggles than me with little or no hope of overcoming them. I've prayed for courage and strength to get through this and my prayers have been answered.  I feel confident to face what the future holds and I have a sense of peace in my heart.  You  and your wife will find that, too, once you get pass the initial shock of the situation.We're here for you and your wife, Kevin.  Please keep us posted.Susan

question: After going to the doctor for unexplained fatigue and blurry vision that i expected was coming from work related stress i was surprised to find out that i was positive for the HCV antibody. I have an appointment with the gastro doc next week and i am a little frustrated that i can not get the blood work done before i go. From my GP the AST/ALT was 48/83 and i tested positive for HCV. The CT was unremarkable on the liver. In going through my files my AST/ALT was elevated last year (44/71) and no one mentioned it and over the last ten years my ALT has been over 50 (in 86 it was in the 30s in rose to 51 and stayed over 50 from 89 forward). I do not drink, have no history of infusions, IVDU or multiple partners. We are terrified that our household practices (sharing of clippers, even toothbrushes in a pinch) we have infected our three children. My wife has had blood infusions 20ys ago, multiple surgeries over the years and we waiting for her results now.Does the normal CT mean that i have no liver problems?Does the eleveated ALT over the years indicate that i may have had the virus longer than i first thought?How can i tell how long i have had the virus?Does the slightly elevated AST/ALT mean that i am only newly infected? Mininumally infected?Is the bioposy the only telltale?Do i need an ultrasound for any reason or is the CT sufficient?How does diabetes fit into this (re DX and TX) I have diet controlled diabetes.How long do i have to wait on the PCR or genotype results normally?I will be 40 next year.ThanksKevin
